Setakat ini, belum pernah exco menghalang pewartaan fatwa.“Apabila mesyuarat Ahli Jawatankuasa Fatwa Negeri memutuskan untuk mewartakan sesuatu fatwa, maka ia terlebih dahulu dikemukakan ke dalam mesyuarat exco oleh Setiausaha Kerajaan Negeri (SUK).“Ia kemudian dihantar ke pejabat Penasihat Undang-undang Negeri untuk diperbaiki susunan katanya dan selepas itu dihantar ke Istana Negara untuk mendapat perkenan Yang di-Pertuan Agong,” kata Wan Salim.Menurut beliau lagi, selepas ia memperoleh perkenan Yang di-Pertuan Agong, SUK akan menghantarnya ke Pejabat Penasihat Undang-undang Negeri untuk tujuan pewartaan.Semalam, Ketua PAS Pulau Pinang Muhammad Fauzi Yusoff mendakwa kerajaan negeri menapis fatwa dalam Majlis Mesyuarat Kerajaan Negeri yang dipengerusikan ketua menteri.Beliau berkata, dalam keadaan biasa, semua fatwa akan terus kepada Yang di-Pertuan Agong untuk diperkenankan bagi setiap negeri yang tidak mempunyai raja.Pada sidang media yang sama, Ketua Pemuda PAS negeri Hafnan Hamimi Taib Azamudden mendakwa fatwa Pulau Pinang tertakluk kepada penelitian exco kerajaan negeri kerana “kesan ke atas masyarakat umum”, antara lain.Hafnan berkata ini berdasarkan penjelasan dibuat exco negeri yang bertanggungjawab bagi hal ehwal agama, Abdul Malik Abul Kassim dalam mesyuarat Jawatankuasa Fatwa negeri.Hafnan, yang juga bekas anggota Jawatankuasa Fatwa negeri mendakwa exco kerajaan negeri “menangguhkan” beberapa fatwa, sambil menambah langkah itu merendahkan martabat institusi Jawatankuasa Fatwa.

Indeed there must be a "decision" as per CoA's Dato Hisyamudin Yunus, which now begs the question whether a requirement to present the edicts to MMKN before presenting them to YDPA is a "decision" by the State which goes against the procedures as stated in Section 48 of the Administration of the Religion of Islam (State of Penang) Enactment 2004 in which allows the YDPA to exercise HRH prerogative right granted by the Fed Consti as the Head of Religion in states without rulers. Order 53 rule 2(4) provides the opportunity to those who are adversely affected by a decision/action/omission in relation to the exercise of a public duty. Did MMKN overstep it boundaries or not? Are the Muslim subjects of YDPA adversely affected by the edict requirement set by MMKN?  Thus in my opinion, wouldn't a judicial review be the better if not the best option to set the record straight?

Judicial review is the correct procedure  if there is a flaw in the decision making process.  Hence as you have correctly pointed out there must be a decision made before one cN lunch a review. In the absence of any decision there cannot be any review.  Unfortunately the Court doesn't entertain academic questions no matter how important to set the record straight. Even if we take the so called directive to present to fatwa to exco  first as a decision, the time limited to review has already long past as a review must be made within 3 months from the said decision. All in all any attempt to file a judicial review is futile at this stage.  Probably a better way to deal with it is to file a civil suit against the Penang government seeking inter alia  that the act of compelling any fatwa  to be presented to the exco  first is unconstitutional.
